name: James Fowler (architect)
content:
James Fowler JP FRIBA (11 December 1828, Lichfield – 10 October 1892, Louth), known as 'Fowler of Louth',[1] is best known as a Victorian English church architect and associated with the restoration and renovation of churches. However, he was also the architect of a wide variety of other buildings. A listing of his work compiled in 1991 traced over 210 buildings that he designed or restored. He is known to be the architect for 24 new churches and his work also included 40 vicarages or rectories, 13 schools, four almshouses, a Savings Bank, a convalescent home and hospital as well as country houses and estate housing. Most of Fowler’s work was in Lincolnshire and particularly around Louth, but it also included work in the East Riding of Yorkshire, Nottinghamshire, Staffordshire, Suffolk, London, Sussex and even Devon.[2]
 Fowler was born in Lichfield. He was a pupil of Lichfield architect Joseph Potter junior.[3] At Louth he was initially in partnership with Joseph Maughan, a surveyor and lithographer in Grimsby. The partnership lasted from 1851 until June  1859.[4].On dissolution it was agreed that the Surveying Department will hereafter be conducted by Mr. Maughan, and the Architectural Department by Mr. Fowler, at their usual places of business in both towns (Grimsby and Louth).[5]   Fowler had  probably continued the practice of Charles John Carter, a Louth architect and surveyor, who had died in 1851. Fowler was elected FRIBA in 1864. Amongst his pupils was Ernest William Farebrother, an architect who worked in Grimsby.[6]  He was a  Surveyor for the Diocese of Lincoln between 1871 and 1886, and was for five terms the mayor of Louth.[7] The Grimsby architect John James Cresswell worked as an articled assistant and then principal assistant to Fowler  between 1877-84.[8]

raw:
James FowlerJames Fowler memorial, Louth ChurchBorn11 December 1828LichfieldDied10 October 1892LouthNationalityEnglishOccupationArchitect
James Fowler JP FRIBA (11 December 1828, Lichfield – 10 October 1892, Louth), known as 'Fowler of Louth',[1] is best known as a Victorian English church architect and associated with the restoration and renovation of churches. However, he was also the architect of a wide variety of other buildings. A listing of his work compiled in 1991 traced over 210 buildings that he designed or restored. He is known to be the architect for 24 new churches and his work also included 40 vicarages or rectories, 13 schools, four almshouses, a Savings Bank, a convalescent home and hospital as well as country houses and estate housing. Most of Fowler’s work was in Lincolnshire and particularly around Louth, but it also included work in the East Riding of Yorkshire, Nottinghamshire, Staffordshire, Suffolk, London, Sussex and even Devon.[2]

Contents

1 Career and architectural practice
2 Works

2.1 Domestic buildings

2.1.1 Houses
2.1.2 Rectories and Vicarages
2.1.3 Almshouses


2.2 Schools
2.3 Public buildings
2.4 Shops


3 Churches

3.1 New or completely rebuilt churches, arranged by date of construction
3.2 Renovated and partially rebuilt churches

3.2.1 Devon
3.2.2 London
3.2.3 Nottinghamshire
3.2.4 Wiltshire
3.2.5 Yorkshire




4 References
5 Further reading
6 External links


Career and architectural practice[edit]
Fowler was born in Lichfield. He was a pupil of Lichfield architect Joseph Potter junior.[3] At Louth he was initially in partnership with Joseph Maughan, a surveyor and lithographer in Grimsby. The partnership lasted from 1851 until June  1859.[4].On dissolution it was agreed that the Surveying Department will hereafter be conducted by Mr. Maughan, and the Architectural Department by Mr. Fowler, at their usual places of business in both towns (Grimsby and Louth).[5]   Fowler had  probably continued the practice of Charles John Carter, a Louth architect and surveyor, who had died in 1851. Fowler was elected FRIBA in 1864. Amongst his pupils was Ernest William Farebrother, an architect who worked in Grimsby.[6]  He was a  Surveyor for the Diocese of Lincoln between 1871 and 1886, and was for five terms the mayor of Louth.[7] The Grimsby architect John James Cresswell worked as an articled assistant and then principal assistant to Fowler  between 1877-84.[8]

Works[edit]
Domestic buildings[edit]
Houses[edit]
 Riversmead, Louth by Fowler 1862
 Lorne House, Queen Street (geograph 4699394)
Dalby – Dalby Hall (1856)[9]
Louth. Riversmead (1862). An example of a town house by Fowler. Contrasting polychrome brickwork with banding and decorative voussiors. Typical gothic arched entrance.
Market Rasen – Grammar School, Headmaster's House (1863)[10]
Langton-by-Partney – Langton Hall (1869)[11]
Stamford – Browne's Hospital (1870)[12]
Stamford – Warden's House (ca. 1870)[13]
Trinity Estates, West Retford. In the 1870s Fowler laid out housing for the Trinity Hospital in Reford. An example of his designs is Lorne House, Queen Street.
Rectories and Vicarages[edit]
Amcotts – Rectory (1882 and 1888)[14]
Goxhill – The Old Vicarage (1872–73)[15]
Gunness – The Old Rectory (1864–66)[16]
Gunness – Stable block (1864–66)[17]
Hatton – Old Rectory (1871). South of the church. Red brick, like the church.[18]
Irby – Old Rectory (1883)[19]
Odstock, Wiltshire – Old Rectory (1869)[20]
Redbourne – The Old Vicarage and Coach House (1861)[21]
Utterby – Rectory (1863)[22]
Waddingham – Old Stainton (was The Old Rectory) (1860)
West Butterwick – The Old Vicarage (1863)[23]
Willoughby – Rectory (1875)[24]
Withcall – Old Rectory (1869)[25]
Wroot – Rectory (1878)[26]
Almshouses[edit]
 Bedehouses, Louth
 Holy Trinity Hospital, West Retford,1872. (geograph 5306266)
Louth – Orme Almshouses (1885)[27]
Louth, Bedehouses Gospelgate. Almshouses on Gospelgate, founded in 1551 and sometimes referred to as King Edward VI's Hospital or Our Lady Bede House as the land formerly belonged to the Guild of St. Mary. The current Grade II listed neo-Tudor building by Fowler in 1868-69.
Fotherby – Allenby Almshouses (1869)[28]
Browne's Hospital, Stamford. 1870. Largely rebuilt by Fowler. Only the S range and part of the west cloister are by Fowler, who rebuilt the rest around an enlarged courtyard.[29]
Holy Trinity Hospital, West Retford.  In 1832–4 the present Hospital was built to the design of Edward Blore. In 1872, Fowler (who had earlier worked on West Retford Church) was commissioned to design a new chapel and audit room. This was added to the centre of the building and at the ground floor, reusing the former common room and converting the space into a chapel. He also added the clock tower. The Hospital is Listed Grade II.[30]

Schools[edit]
 King Edward VI Grammar School, Louth 1868
 De Aston Grammar School, Market Rasen 1861-3
Caistor – Caistor Primary School and School House (1859–60)[31]
East Ravendale – School[32]
Louth – parts of Edward VI Grammar School (1866)[27]
Market Rasen – De Aston School (1862), red brick headmaster's house with associated school buildings.[33]
Public buildings[edit]
Grimsby – Town Hall (1861–63). Constructed to designs by Bellamy and Hardy of Lincoln and the London architect John Giles. Fowler acted as superintending architect during construction.[34]
Horncastle High Street – Corn Exchange by Maugham and Fowler (1855).[35] Erected in 1856 at a cost of about £3500, was a handsome edifice of brick with stone facings, and included a newsroom, a mechanics' institute with a library, and a hall for assemblies, concerts, and lectures. It was later converted into the Victory Cinema.
Shops[edit]
 Spar 15 Market place, Louth, Lincolnshire
15 Market Place, Louth.c.1865. Venetian Gothic Revival derived style with polychrome decorated brick facade. Formerly the International Stores and now Spar.[36]

Churches[edit]
New or completely rebuilt churches, arranged by date of construction[edit]
 St.Martin's church, East Ravendale, Lincs.
East Ravendale, St. Martin (1857)[37]
Winceby, St Margaret (1860). Now demolished.[38]
Wold Newton, All Hallows (1862)[39]
Louth, St Michael (1862–3)[40]
Frampton, St. Michael (1863).
Ludford, St Mary & St Peter (1863-5)
Cleethorpes, St Peter (1864–66)[41]
Snitterby, St Nicholas (1866)
Lichfield, St Mary (1868–70)[42]
Lincoln, St Swithin's (1869-87). Nikolaus Pevsner described this as "without doubt his most important church." [43]
Binbrook, Sts Mary and Gabriel (1869)[44]
Hatton, St. Stephen (1870). According to Pevsner this is one of Fowler’s more satisfying small churches. Red brick with bands of stone.[18]
 Interior, St Stephens church, Hatton
London, Kenley, All Saints (1870–72)
Newington, St Mary (1886)[45]
Temple Bruer, St John (1874)[46]
Spridlington, St Hilary (1875). Erected in 1875 to replace an earlier church, which was dedicated to St Hilary and St Albinus, so named as there were originally two churches in the village; St Hilary and St Albinus. The present church was built in memory of the Rector, Rev H F Hutton, who was incumbent for thirty-two years.[47]
Moorhouses, St Laurence (1875)[48]
Alford Cemetery Chapel and curator's lodge (1881). Fowler was architect and Mr. Henry Kidd of Alford the builder, completed October 8, 1881 at a cost of £785. The buildings are joined by a Gothic archway for carriages. The floor is laid with Minton's ornamental tiles, the interior walls are of red brick to the moulded string course, and mixture above, with Gothic panelled arches. There is a bell turret with a bell of 75lb weight.[49][50]
Sutton-in-Ashfield, St Michael and All Angels', Nottinghamshire (1887)[51] (chancel only)
 St. Swithin's church, Lincoln
Renovated and partially rebuilt churches[edit]

Benington, Lincolnshire – All Saints (1873)[52]
 St.Julian's church, Benniworth, Lincs. - geograph.org.uk - 73382
Benniworth, St Julian[53]
Blyborough, St Alkmund (1877–88)[54]
Brattleby, St Cuthbert (1858)[55]
Clarborough, St John the Baptist[56]
Bucknall, St Margaret (1884)[57]
Claxby – St Mary (1871)[58]
Colsterworth, St John Baptist (1876)[59]
Croxton, St John the Evangelist (1876)[60]
Cuxwold, St Nicholas (1860)[61]
Dalby – St Lawrence and Bishop Edward King (1862)[62]
East Halton, St Peter (1868)[63]
Edlington, St Helen (1859–60)[64]
 St Mary's church Fotherby - geograph.org.uk - 96899
Fotherby, St Mary (1863)[65]
Frampton, St Michael (1863)[66]
Gedney Hill, Holy Trinity (1875)[67]
Grayingham, St Radegund (1870)[68]
 Great Carlton Church, Lincolnshire 01
 St.John the Baptist's church, Great Carlton, Lincs. - geograph.org.uk - 108075
Great Carlton – Church of St John Baptist (1860)[69]
Grimsby – Church of  Holy Trinity and Holy Mary (1878)[70]
Gunby – Church of St Peter (1868–70)[71][72]
Hagworthingham, Holy Trinity (1859)[73]
Halton Holegate, St Andrew (1866)[74]
Healing, St Peter and St Paul (1874–76)[75]
Heckington, St Andrew (1887–88)[76]
Hibaldstow, St Hybald (1875)[77]
Irby, Saint Andrew (1883)[78]
Laceby, Saint Margaret (1883)[79]
Lenton – St Peter (1879)[80]
Leverton  St Helen (1892)[81]
Louth, St James (1861–69)[82]
Ludborough, St Mary (1858)[83]
Ludford Magna, St Mary and St Peter (1864)[84]
Market Deeping, St Guthlac (1875[85] or 1878[86])
Market Rasen, St Thomas (1862)[87]
Mavis Enderby, St Michael (1875)[88]
Miningsby, St Andrew (1878). Demolished 1980.[89]
Moorby, All Saints (1866), Demolished 1983.[89]
Muckton, Holy Trinity (1878–79) Demolished 1983.[89] Pevsner, Nikolaus; Harris, John; The Buildings of England: Lincolnshire p. 319
Nettleton, St John Baptist (1874)[90]
New Clee, St John (1879)
Newton by Toft – St Michael (1860)[91]
Normanby le Wold, St Peter (1868)[92]
North Coates, St Nicholas (1865)[93]
Old Bolingbroke, St Peter and St Paul (1890)[94]
Ranby – St German (1861)[95]
Rigsby – St James (1863)[96]
Roxby, St Mary (1875)[97]
Saltfleetby by St Peter, St Peter (1877)[98]
Scawby, St Hybald (1870)[99]
Sixhills, All Saints (1869 and 1875)[100]
Skegness – St Clements (1884)[101]
Skegness, St Matthew (1879–80)[102][103]
Snitterby, St Nicholas (1866)[104]
South Ormsby, St Leonard (1871–72)[105]
South Reston, St Edith (1864–65)[106]
Stainfield  St Andrew[107]
Stewton, St Andrew (1886)[108]
Tealby All Saints (1872)[109]
Thimbleby – St Margaret (1879)[110]
Thoresway, St Mary (1879–80)[111]
Thornton Curtis, St Lawrence (1884)[112]
Toynton St Peter, St Peter (1876)[113]
Upton – All Saints (1874–75 and 1880)[114]
Waithe  St Martin, (1861)[115]
Waltham – Church of All Saints (1867 and 1874)[116]
Willoughby – St Helen. Chancel rebuilt by Fowler.(1880)[117]
Wilsthorpe – St Faith (1869)[118]
Wroot – St Pancras (1878)[119]
Wyham cum Cadeby  All Saints (1886)[120]
Devon[edit]
Georgeham, Devon.  St George (1876)[121]
London[edit]
Croydon, All Saints (1870–72)[122]
Nottinghamshire[edit]
Bole – St John Baptist (1874)[123]
Boughton, St Matthew (1868)[124]
Nuthall – St Patrick, Nottinghamshire (1884)[125]
Retford - St Michael the Archangel (1863).[126]
Wiltshire[edit]
Odstock, Wiltshire – St Mary (1870)[127]
Yorkshire[edit]
Bainton St Andrew (1866)[128]
Beswick  St Margaret (1871)[129]
Easby – St Agatha (1881)[130]
Harswell, St Peter (1871)[131]
Moor Monkton, Yorkshire. All Saints (1879)[132][133]
Skipsea, Yorkshire, All Saints (1856–60)[134]
